Award.AwardTitle: MRI-R2: Acquisition of Equipment for Rare Earth Spectroscopic Studies of Sol-Gel Glass Structure
Award.AbstractNarration:
0959552
Boye
Davidson College

Technical Summary:
This award is funded under the American Recovery and Reinvestment Act of 2009 (Public Law 111-5).

Sol-gel derived glass containing fluorescing rare earth (RE) ions are potentially useful in applications such as lasers, optical sensors, and fiber optic and photonic devices. However, the optical behavior of RE-doped sol-gel glasses is not yet fully understood. The work proposed here will use optical spectroscopy to answer fundamental questions about the ways that sol-gel glass structure influences RE fluorescence yield. Two primary non-radiative decay mechanisms have been identified: deactivation through vibrational excitation of neighboring hydroxyl complexes and the silica matrix, and energy transfer among clustered RE ions on pore surfaces. This project will explore new synthesis techniques, including the use of drying control chemical agents in the starting solutions, to reduce fluorescence quenching. RE ions will be used as spectroscopic probes of structural parameters such as pore connectivity to aid in identifying the most effective methods for minimizing the RE-hydroxyl interactions. In addition, studies of energy transfer among RE ions will be used to explore how RE ion distribution in the porous sol-gel matrix correlates with synthesis protocols. These measurements will be crucial in optimizing the optical performance of these materials by achieving a more uniform distribution of RE ions in the glass. The goal is to obtain a deeper understanding of the fluorescence behavior of the RE ions, leading to a new class of more efficient fluorescent materials for the applications listed above. Our innovative research program in materials science involves collaboration between faculty and students at three undergraduate liberal arts colleges - Davidson, Hamilton, and Whitman Colleges. The new equipment provided by this grant will expand each laboratory's unique ability to perform time-based and cw spectroscopies. Undergraduate students will be involved in every aspect of this cross-disciplinary project and will benefit from increased opportunities to perform research with state-of-the-art equipment at the different participating colleges.


Layman Summary:
This award is funded under the American Recovery and Reinvestment Act of 2009 (Public Law 111-5).

Sol-gel materials have interesting uses in a surprisingly broad range of disciplines - from coatings on aircraft to hosts for biologically active enzymes. The sol-gel glass process uses readily available starting materials and relatively low temperatures to produce glasses with optical behavior comparable to glasses made by the traditional melt process. Creating new optical materials that are potentially useful in applications such as phosphor lighting, lasers, optical sensors, and fiber optic and photonic devices is the focus of our efforts. Our innovative research program in materials science involves collaboration between faculty and students at three undergraduate liberal arts colleges - Davidson, Hamilton, and Whitman Colleges. By leveraging the strengths of our individual laboratories, we will continue to make significant progress in understanding the ways that energy is absorbed, transferred and released by fluorescing Rare Earth (RE) ions in the glass. Undergraduate students are involved at all stages of this research process from grant writing to experimental design and implementation and on to publication in refereed journals and presentations at professional meetings. In fact, two of our recent students have received national recognition for their research. The new equipment provided by this grant will greatly expand each laboratory's unique ability to examine the time evolution and energy distribution of light emitted by RE ions in these materials. Building on the existing synergy of our collaboration, an increased number of students will be provided with more varied opportunities to explore cutting edge scientific ideas while working with state-of-the-art equipment. Our scientific goals are to obtain a deeper understanding of the interaction among RE ions, and between RE ions and their glass host, leading to a new class of more efficient fluorescent materials available for optical applications.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Title: Rare Earths in Sol-Gel Glasses
NSF MRI-R2 Award: 0959552
PI: Daniel M. Boye, Davidson College
co-PI: Ann J. Silversmith, Hamilton College
co-PI: Kurt R. Hoffman, Whitman College

Toward new and better fluorescent glasses

Intellectual Merit:  Fluorescent materials impact our lives in many ways.  Such materials, also called  “phosphors," are often made by embedding small amounts of rare-earth ions in an optically-clear crystal or glass host material.  One such host material with many favorable synthesis and application  properties is glass made by the sol-gel (solution-gelation) process. 
Sol-gel materials have interesting uses in an amazingly broad range of applications – from coatings on aircraft and artwork to hosts for biologically active enzymes. In our research efforts, we study the fluorescing properties of sol-gel derived glass containing rare earth (RE) impurity ions. These glasses are potentially useful in applications such as lasers, optical sensors, and photonic devices. However, the optical behavior of RE-doped sol-gel glasses is not yet fully understood. Our research project uses optical spectroscopy to achieve a deeper understanding of the ways that the porous nature of sol-gel glasses affects optical behavior, and to improve the optical performance of RE-doped sol-gel glasses.

Undergraduate researchers and faculty at Davidson, Hamilton and Whitman Colleges have developed and refined the new analysis technique, Post Annealing Immersion (PAI) (see Figure 1).  In PAI, porous glasses are immersed in solutions of rare earth ions. The solutions diffuse into the pores, and subsequent drying removes the solvent, leaving RE dopants behind.  Using this technique, we have shown that dopants ions lie on the pore surfaces of these glasses, a very different environment than provided by crystals or melt glasses.

We have studied the transfer of energy from Yb (ytterbium) ions to Er (erbium) ions in sol-gel glasses through infrared to visible light upconversion (see Figure 2). Yb ions are excited by an infrared laser and act as a reservoir of energy to be transferred to Er ions.  Two sequential transfers of energy result in an excited Er ion that emits green light. The rate of energy transfer depends on the spatial separation between the ions.  Figure 2 also shows how the turn on and decay of the green light changes with the number of Yb ions in a pore.  For the highest concentration of Yb (olive green trace) in which the Yb:Er ratio is 40:1, the slowest turn on and decay occurs. These changes in the upconversion emission provide information on both the energy transfer rates between ions and the relative distribution of ions within a pore. We have developed a computer model for this unique energy transfer process.

We have also broadened the scope of our research to include crystalline nanoparticles, self-assembled polymer nanoparticles and chelated molecular crystals. Incorporating nanoparticles and chelated REs into the sol-gel matrix produces glasses with different fluorescent behavior.  With the knowledge we have gained through the work of this project, there many new avenues that our students will explore using the equipment funded through this grant.

Broader Impact: This research project in materials science continues a fruitful collaboration between Davidson, Hamilton, and Whitman Colleges whose strongest impact is in the mentoring and training of future scientists at the undergraduate level.
